awd_titl_txt: Role of Mesoscale Ocean Dynamics in Air-Sea Coupling over the Southern Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
The atmosphere and ocean interact on a wide range of spatial and temporal scales, and these interactions modulate weather and climate variability, as well as oceanic uptake of anomalous heat and carbon. At the oceanic mesoscale (about 10 to 100 km scales), advection is sufficiently strong to create strong gradients in sea surface temperature. As air blows across these very sharp fronts, the atmosphere cannot fully adjust, which leads to significant effects such as atmospheric cooling (warming) of warm (cold) sea surface temperatures. These effects are well pronounced in the Southern Ocean, where powerful mesoscale variability abounds. The main goal of this project is to explore mesoscale atmosphere-ocean interactions in the Southern Ocean and to understand how the ocean mesoscale creates sharp sea surface temperature fronts that modulate these interactions. This study will serve to inform global climate modeling efforts in terms of the identifying the key processes and required ocean resolution needed to correctly capture air-sea interactions. The project will advance a career of a female investigator and will train two graduate students in the fields of Physical Oceanography and Climate Science.

Atmosphere-ocean coupling at mesoscale plays an important, but poorly understood role in climate variability, atmosphere and ocean dynamics, uptake of atmospheric gases and biogeochemistry. Understanding of this coupling has large practical importance for climate modeling, because a vast majority of climate models cannot fully resolve the mesoscale, which leads to biases in the simulations. The main hypothesis of this project is that a significant part of the sea surface temperature anomaly variability at the oceanic mesoscale is driven by mesoscale oceanic advection. The analysis will be carried out in a fully coupled model system in which mesoscale sea surface temperature anomalies both affect and are affected by the atmosphere, and the study will employ a blend of advanced theoretical considerations, comprehensive coupled simulations and targeted idealized studies, all with high resolution in the ocean. The particular focus of this study is on the Southern Ocean, both because of its large role in climate and because mesoscale variability is ubiquitous there, but our conclusions are expected to be relevant to the other parts of the World Ocean.  One particular strength of this research is the merging of comprehensive climate simulations with a combination of idealized modeling and theory, in a fully coupled regime and with dynamically consistent mesoscale ocean circulation.

por.por_cntn:
The atmosphere and ocean interact on a wide range of spatial scales. These interactions influence weather and climate, as well as oceanic intake of extra heat from the atmosphere. Of particular importance are the spatial scales of tens to hundreds of kilometers in the ocean, which are called ?mesoscales?. The corresponding mesoscale ocean currents tend to be very strong and highly variable, and they can create rapid changes (anomalies) in the Sea-Surface Temperature (SST), which force the atmosphere to respond. Understanding of these processes has large practical importance for climate modeling, because vast majority of climate models cannot fully capture mesoscale dynamics. The focus of this study is on understanding the regime at which vigorous oceanic variability drives the atmospheric response and controls the amount of heat taken from the atmosphere.

Most climate models lack sufficient spatial resolution needed to represent mesoscale processes in the ocean, and this shortcoming can negatively impact the ability of these models to simulate present climate and make climate predictions. This study is based on high-resolution atmosphere-ocean models and focuses on the Southern Ocean, where these effects are generally strong. Our results show that resolving mesoscale processes leads to improvement in decadal predictions, and the effect is particularly notable in the Southern Ocean. Another example of the importance of mesoscale dynamics is associated with inconsistency between the observed and model-simulated Southern Ocean warming. The largest difference is found in the south of the region, where both observations and a model that resolves the mesoscale exhibit cooling, in contrast to a model that cannot resolve the mesoscale and shows a warming trend.

We developed a new Regional Ocean-Atmosphere Model (ROAM) which successfully reproduces interactions between SST anomalies, surface winds and heat exchanges between the atmosphere and ocean. The accuracy, flexible design and efficiency of the model make it a useful tool for studies of the mesoscale atmosphere-ocean interactions.  The results from ROAM show that these interactions depend on the spatial scale and the relationship between large-size winds and SST anomalies is noticeably stronger than the relationship between the small-size anomalies.

ROAM is further used to reveal the importance of oceanic currents for the exchanges of heat between the atmosphere and ocean, emergence of SST anomalies and overall changes in density. The oceanic currents are shown to create mesoscale SST anomalies, while the atmosphere acts to dampen these anomalies. In addition to the oceanic currents, this process also depends on the thickness of the oceanic mixed layer, which is the topmost part of the ocean that immediately interacts with the atmosphere. Because this layer is well-mixed vertically, a very deep mixed layer makes the ocean less sensitive to heating and cooling by the atmosphere. We further show that oceanic currents play a key role in the variability of the mixed layer by redistributing density of water. This effect is shown to work against the atmospheric forcing and vertical mixing. As a result of this complex balance, the relation between SST and mixed layer thickness is weak in regions with strong oceanic currents. The revealed importance of the mesoscale ocean dynamics in the variability of mixed layer is further confirmed in realistic climate simulations. 

Atmosphere-ocean coupling at mesoscale plays an important, but poorly understood role in climate variability, atmosphere and ocean dynamics, uptake of atmospheric gases and biogeochemistry. Our particular focus in this study is on the Southern Ocean, both because of its large role in climate and because mesoscale variability is ubiquitous there, but our conclusions are expected to be relevant to the other parts of the World Ocean. In addition to its importance for Physical Oceanography, this study will have implications for a wide scientific community in Atmospheric Sciences, Chemical Oceanography and Climate Science. The results will serve to inform global climate modeling efforts in terms of the identifying the key processes and required ocean resolution needed to correctly capture air-sea interactions and climate change.
